The image was manipulated: The expert's verdict clearly states that the viral image showing Whoopi Goldberg wearing a shirt with a cartoon of President Donald Trump firing a gun at himself was manipulated. This aspect was employed to verify the authenticity of the claim.
Original photograph evidence: The expert mentions that the original photograph, taken at the Women's March in New York on January 21, 2017, shows Goldberg wearing a different shirt that read, "And you thought I was a nasty woman before? Buckle up, buttercup." This original photograph serves as evidence to debunk the claim.
Video footage on The View: Goldberg showed the original shirt she wore using video footage on The View on April 18, 2017, when the image first surfaced. This aspect of providing video evidence helps in verifying the authenticity of the claim.
Goldberg: s statement: Goldberg herself addressed the manipulated image and clarified that it was a lie. She stated, "A photo of me at the Women's March has been photoshopped to show me wearing an offensive shirt against you-know-who. Even though I don't care for this man, I would never wear this shirt that's there." Her statement adds weight to the debunking of the claim.
